name: Aphrodite
title: Greek - Aphrodite
description:
Aphrodite stands as one of the most iconic and influential figures in Greek mythology. Revered as the deity of Foam-Born, Cyprian, Cytherea, Aphrodite embodies the fundamental forces that shape both the divine and mortal realms. 

According to Greek sacred texts, Aphrodite's origins trace back to the primordial age, emerging from the cosmic struggle between Titans and Olympians The worship of Aphrodite became central to Greek religious practice, with devotees seeking their favor through temple sacrifices, libations, and participation in sacred festivals. 

Sacred symbols associated with Aphrodite include Dove, swan, rose. These emblems appear throughout Greek art and literature, serving as powerful reminders of Aphrodite's divine presence and authority. The mythology surrounding Aphrodite reveals deep insights into Greek worldview, particularly concerning Foam-Born and humanity's relationship with the divine. 

The legacy of Aphrodite extends far beyond ancient Greek civilization. References to Aphrodite pervade Western literature, from Renaissance poetry to modern novels. The archetype continues to influence psychology, philosophy, and popular culture Scholars continue to study Aphrodite's mythology for its profound insights into Greek culture, religion, and philosophy.
role: Goddess of Love, Beauty, and Desire

worship.sacred_sites: Aphrodite 's primary cult centers were on Cyprus (especially Paphos, where she was said to have come ashore) and Cythera. Major temples also existed at Corinth (where temple prostitution was practiced), Athens, and throughout the Greek world. Her sanctuaries were often near the sea or in gardens.
festivals: Aphrodisia: Celebrated throughout Greece in midsummer, honoring Aphrodite with processions, offerings of flowers, and private celebrations of love and beauty.
Adonia: Women-only festival mourning Adonis and celebrating his resurrection, featuring gardens planted in his honor that quickly bloomed and withered.
worship.offerings: Worshippers offered flowers (especially roses and myrtle), perfumes, incense, doves, and personal items of beauty. Her altars received garlands and wreaths. Unlike gods receiving blood sacrifices, offerings to Aphrodite emphasized beauty, fragrance, and sensual pleasure.
worship.prayers: Aphrodite was invoked for matters of love, marriage, fertility, and beauty. Prayers often appealed to her power over desire and her ability to grant favor in romantic pursuits. Sailors also prayed to her for safe sea voyages, honoring her birth from the sea.

archetype_description: Aphrodite embodies the Love Goddess archetype - divine beauty, desire, and the transformative power of passion.

listDisplay.expandedContent: Born from the sea foam, Aphrodite embodies love, beauty, pleasure, and procreation. Her powers extend to gods and mortals alike, causing desire, passion, and sometimes chaos in matters of the heart.

sections.title: Description
sections.content: Born from the sea foam, Aphrodite embodies love, beauty, pleasure, and procreation. Her powers extend to gods and mortals alike, causing desire, passion, and sometimes chaos in matters of the heart.

sections.title: Family
items: Children: eros (cupid), harmonia, phobos, deimos (by ares), aeneas (by anchises), hermaphroditus (by hermes), god of love, charm

summary: Born from the sea foam, Aphrodite embodies love, beauty, pleasure, and procreation.  Her powers extend to gods and mortals alike, causing desire, passion, and sometimes chaos in matters of the heart.
cultural_significance: Embodies divine love, beauty, and desire

topic_panels.title: Origins & Mythology
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Origins

Aphrodite's mythology primordial chaos, Titans, Olympians. The deity's role in Greek cosmology reflects fundamental aspects of how ancient peoples understood divine power and cosmic order.

### Creation Accounts

Primary sources describe Aphrodite's emergence and divine nature through various sacred narratives. These origin stories served both religious and cultural functions, establishing divine authority and cosmic principles.

**Time Period:** c. 800 BCE - 400 CE

topic_panels.title: Worship & Practice
topic_panels.content:
### Religious Practice

Worship of Aphrodite involved temple sacrifices, festivals, oracles. These practices created sacred bonds between devotees and the divine realm.

### Sacred Sites

Throughout Ancient Greece, Mediterranean basin, temples and shrines dedicated to Aphrodite served as focal points for religious activity. Priests and priestesses maintained sacred rituals that ensured divine favor and cosmic balance.

### Festivals & Ceremonies

Special festivals celebrated Aphrodite's divine attributes and mythological deeds, bringing communities together in shared religious expression.

topic_panels.title: Symbols & Iconography
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Symbols

Key symbols associated with Aphrodite:

- **Dove**: Represents divine power and sacred authority
- **swan**: Represents divine power and sacred authority
- **rose**: Represents divine power and sacred authority
- **myrtle**: Represents divine power and sacred authority
- **scallop shell**: Represents divine power and sacred authority

### Divine Attributes

As deity of Foam-Born, Cyprian, Cytherea, Laughter-Loving, Golden Aphrodite, Love, beauty, desire, sexuality, pleasure, procreation, Aphrodite embodies these cosmic principles. The iconography reveals how ancient peoples visualized divine power and cosmic forces.

### Artistic Representations

Ancient artworks depict Aphrodite with distinctive attributes that communicate divine identity and authority to worshippers.

topic_panels.title: Modern Influence
topic_panels.content:
### Cultural Legacy

Western literature, psychology, philosophy. The mythology of Aphrodite continues to resonate in contemporary culture, literature, and spiritual practices.

### Academic Study

Modern scholars analyze Aphrodite's mythology through multiple lenses‚Äîreligious studies, anthropology, archaeology, and comparative mythology‚Äîrevealing insights into ancient worldviews.

### Popular Culture

Aphrodite appears in modern media, from fantasy novels to video games, demonstrating the enduring power of ancient mythology to capture human imagination and address timeless questions.

related_myths.title: Aphrodite and the Divine Council
related_myths.summary: Stories of Aphrodite's interactions with other deities, revealing the complex relationships and hierarchies of the Greek pantheon.

related_myths.title: Aphrodite and the Gift of Foam-Born
related_myths.summary: The mythological account of how Aphrodite became associated with Foam-Born and bestowed this gift upon humanity or the cosmos.

related_myths.title: The Legacy of Aphrodite
related_myths.summary: How Aphrodite's actions and teachings continue to influence the world, establishing sacred traditions and cosmic principles.
